message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Ergodicity Breaking Arising from Hilbert Space Fragmentation in Dipole-Conserving Hamiltonians
Paper Abstract: We show that the combination of charge and dipole conservation---characteristic of fracton systems---leads to an extensive fragmentation of the Hilbert space, which in turn can lead to a breakdown of thermalization. As a concrete example, we investigate the out-of-equilibrium dynamics of one-dimensional spin-1 models that conserve charge (total $S^z$) and its associated dipole moment. First, we consider a minimal model including only three-site terms and find that the infinite temperature auto-correlation saturates to a finite value---showcasing non-thermal behavior. The absence of thermalization is identified as a consequence of the strong fragmentation of the Hilbert space into exponentially many invariant subspaces in the local $S^z$ basis, arising from the interplay of dipole conservation and local interactions. Second, we extend the model by including four-site terms and find that this perturbation leads to a weak fragmentation: the system still has exponentially many invariant subspaces, but they are no longer sufficient to avoid thermalization for typical initial states. More generally, for any finite range of interactions, the system still exhibits non-thermal eigenstates appearing throughout the entire spectrum. We compare our results to charge and dipole moment conserving random unitary circuit models for which we reach identical conclusions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Hilbert spaces:

## Definition

A Hilbert space is a real or complex inner product space that is also a complete metric space with respect to the metric induced by the inner product.(no content)It generalizes the notion of Euclidean space to infinite dimensions.

## Key Properties

The inner product, which is the analog of the dot product from vector calculus, allows lengths and angles to be defined.(no content)Furthermore, completeness means that there are enough limits in the space to allow the techniques of calculus to be used.

## Historical Development

Hilbert spaces were studied beginning in the first decade of the 20th century by David Hilbert, Erhard Schmidt, and Frigyes Riesz.(no content)John von Neumann coined the term Hilbert space for the abstract concept that underlies many of these diverse applications.

## Applications

They are indispensable tools in the theories of partial differential equations, quantum mechanics, Fourier analysis (which includes applications to signal processing and heat transfer), and ergodic theory (which forms the mathematical underpinning of thermodynamics).

## Examples and Variations

Apart from the classical Euclidean vector spaces, examples of Hilbert spaces include spaces of square-integrable functions, spaces of sequences, Sobolev spaces consisting of generalized functions, and Hardy spaces of holomorphic functions.

Web search results for query: "Fracton topological order"

Links: [{"title":"Fracton (subdimensional particle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fracton_(subdimensional_particle)"},{"title":"Topological order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_order"},{"title":"Topological sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_sorting"},{"title":"Fracton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fracton"},{"title":"Symmetry-protected topological order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry-protected_topological_order"},{"title":"Fractal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractals"},{"title":"Fractional quantum Hall effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_quantum_Hall_effect"},{"title":"Fractional Chern insulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_Chern_insulator"},{"title":"Topological defect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_defect"},{"title":"Topological quantum field theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topological_quantum_field_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about fracton topological order:

## Fracton Topological Order

A fracton is an emergent topological quasiparticle excitation which is immobile when in isolation.(no content)Many theoretical systems have been proposed in which fractons exist as elementary excitations, and such systems are known as fracton models.

### Key Characteristics

Fracton models do not have the property that the ground state degeneracy depends only on the topology of the manifold on which the system is embedded, because the ground state degeneracy also depends on system size.(no content)Among the gapped phases of fracton models, there is a non-rigorous phenomenological classification into "type I" and "type II". Type I fracton models generally have fracton excitations that are completely immobile, as well as other excitations, including bound states, with restricted mobility. Type II fracton models generally have fracton excitations and no mobile particles of any form.

### Classification and Theory

Fractons have been identified in various CSS codes as well as in symmetric tensor gauge theories.(no content)The concept of foliated fracton order resolves the issue of unconventional ground state degeneracy by allowing degenerate subsystems (two-dimensional gapped topological phases) to be used as "free resources" that can be arbitrarily added or removed from the system to account for these differences.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Random unitary circuit quantum"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum random circuits - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_random_circuits"},{"title":"Quantum circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_circuit"},{"title":"Quantum logic gate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_logic_gate"},{"title":"Random matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gaussian_Unitary_Ensemble"},{"title":"Hadamard test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadamard_test"},{"title":"Quantum t-design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_t-design"},{"title":"One-way quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_quantum_computer"},{"title":"List of quantum logic gates - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_quantum_logic_gates"},{"title":"Quantum supremacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_supremacy"},{"title":"Choi–Jamiołkowski isomorphism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Choi%E2%80%93Jamio%C5%82kowski_isomorphism"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about random unitary circuits in quantum computing:

## Overview

Quantum random circuits (QRC) is a concept of incorporating an element of randomness into the local unitary operations and measurements of a quantum circuit.

## Applications

Random unitary circuits have several important applications:

1. **Quantum Supremacy Demonstrations**: Sampling the output of random quantum circuits is a proposal to demonstrate quantum supremacy, where the output distributions obtained by making measurements are flat but structured in a way so that one cannot classically efficiently sample from a distribution that is close to the distribution generated by the quantum experiment.

2. **Quantum Optics**: In quantum optics, transformations described by random unitary matrices are crucial for demonstrating the advantage of quantum over classical computation (see, e.g., the boson sampling model).(no content)Such random unitary transformations can be directly implemented in an optical circuit, by mapping their parameters to optical circuit components (that is beam splitters and phase shifters).

3. **Quantum Computing Benchmarking**: The theory of unitary 2-designs was developed in 2006 specifically to achieve a practical means of efficient and scalable randomized benchmarking to assess the errors in quantum computing operations, called gates.

## Historical Context

In Google's claim of quantum supremacy, they used their sycamore processor, which took about 200 seconds to sample one instance of a quantum circuit a million times, while a state-of-the-art classical supercomputer would take 10,000 years.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Ergodicity breaking"

Links: [{"title":"Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_hypothesis"},{"title":"Ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity"},{"title":"Ergodicity economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity_economics"},{"title":"Ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_process"},{"title":"Ergodic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_theory"},{"title":"Quantum ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_ergodicity"},{"title":"Quantum scar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_scar"},{"title":"Stationary ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_ergodic_process"},{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Talk:Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ergodic_hypothesis"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about **ergodicity breaking**:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In macroscopic systems, the timescales over which a system can truly explore the entirety of its own phase space can be sufficiently large that the thermodynamic equilibrium state exhibits some form of ergodicity breaking.

## Physical Examples

A common example is that of spontaneous magnetisation in ferromagnetic systems, whereby below the Curie temperature the system preferentially adopts a non-zero magnetisation even though the ergodic hypothesis would imply that no net magnetisation should exist by virtue of the system exploring all states whose time-averaged magnetisation should be zero.(no content)The fact that macroscopic systems often violate the literal form of the ergodic hypothesis is an example of spontaneous symmetry breaking.

## Complex Systems

Complex disordered systems such as a spin glass show an even more complicated form of ergodicity breaking where the properties of the thermodynamic equilibrium state seen in practice are much more difficult to predict purely by symmetry arguments.

## Quantum Systems

In quantum mechanics, ergodicity breaking also occurs. In a quantum system, classical ergodic behavior can break down, as exemplified by the presence of quantum scars. Additionally, there are two other types of quantum scarring, which further illustrate the weak-ergodicity breaking in quantum chaotic systems: perturbation-induced and many-body quantum scars.

## Applications in Economics

The emerging field of ergodicity economics is beginning to show how including non-ergodic dynamics addresses some of the criticisms of neoclassical and pluralist economics.

Web search results for query: "Eigenstate quantum mechanics"

Links: [{"title":"Quantum state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_state"},{"title":"Stationary state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_state"},{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Quantum mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_mechanics"},{"title":"Eigenfunction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenfunction"},{"title":"Observable - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable"},{"title":"Eigenspinor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenspinor"},{"title":"Position operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Position_operator"},{"title":"Complete set of commuting observables - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_set_of_commuting_observables"},{"title":"Momentum operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Momentum_operator"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of eigenstates in quantum mechanics:

## Definition

A quantum state can be an eigenvector of an observable, in which case it is called an eigenstate, and the associated eigenvalue corresponds to the value of the observable in that eigenstate.

## Key Properties

An eigenstate with a specific eigenvalue would be a quantum state with a definite, well-defined value of that observable, with no quantum uncertainty.(no content)If its observable were measured, the result is guaranteed to be the corresponding eigenvalue.

## Relationship to Measurements

If a system is in an eigenstate of an observable and only that observable is measured, all runs of the experiment will yield the same result. However, if you measure a different incompatible observable first and then measure the original observable, the system will transfer to an eigenstate of the first observable after the first measurement, and the results of the second observable will generally be statistical.

## Superposition

A pure state described as a superposition of multiple different eigenstates does in general have quantum uncertainty for the given observable.

## Energy Eigenstates

A special case of eigenstates are energy eigenstates. An energy eigenstate is an eigenvector of the energy operator (rather than a quantum superposition of different energies), and is also called an energy eigenvector, energy eigenfunction, or energy eigenket.

Web search results for query: "Charge conservation physics"

Links: [{"title":"Charge conservation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge_conservation"},{"title":"Continuity equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuity_equation"},{"title":"Conserved current - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conserved_current"},{"title":"Conservation law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_law"},{"title":"Noether's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noether's_theorem"},{"title":"Charge invariance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge_invariance"},{"title":"Electric charge - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_charge"},{"title":"C parity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C_parity"},{"title":"Charge (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge_(physics)"},{"title":"Conserved quantity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conserved_quantities"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of charge conservation in physics based on the search results:

## Definition and Principle

Charge conservation is the principle, of experimental nature, that the total electric charge in an isolated system never changes. More specifically, the net quantity of electric charge, the amount of positive charge minus the amount of negative charge in the universe, is always conserved.

## How It Works

Charge conservation, considered as a physical conservation law, implies that the change in the amount of electric charge in any volume of space is exactly equal to the amount of charge flowing into the volume minus the amount of charge flowing out of the volume.

## In Particle Physics

In particle physics, charge conservation means that in reactions that create charged particles, equal numbers of positive and negative particles are always created, keeping the net amount of charge unchanged.(no content)Similarly, when particles are destroyed, equal numbers of positive and negative charges are destroyed.

## Theoretical Foundation

Charge conservation can be understood as a consequence of symmetry through Noether's theorem, a central result in theoretical physics that asserts that each conservation law is associated with a symmetry of the underlying physics. The symmetry that is associated with charge conservation is the global gauge invariance of the electromagnetic field.

## Experimental Support

This property is supported without exception by all empirical observations so far.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Thermalisation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermalisation"},{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Many-body localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_localization"},{"title":"Two temperature model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two_temperature_model"},{"title":"David A. Huse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_A._Huse"},{"title":"Thermal physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermal_physics"},{"title":"Statistical mechanics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Statistical_mechanics"},{"title":"Stochastic thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft:Stochastic_Thermodynamics"},{"title":"Thermal fluctuations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermal_fluctuation"},{"title":"Quantum thermodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_thermodynamics"}]

Here are the search results for thermalization in statistical mechanics:

## Definition and Core Concept

Thermalization (or thermalisation) is the process of physical bodies reaching thermal equilibrium through mutual interaction.(no content)In general, the natural tendency of a system is towards a state of equipartition of energy and uniform temperature that maximizes the system's entropy.

## Quantum Thermalization and the Eigenstate Thermalization Hypothesis

A major focus in modern statistical mechanics is understanding how isolated quantum systems thermalize. The eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) is a set of ideas which purports to explain when and why an isolated quantum mechanical system can be accurately described using equilibrium statistical mechanics, particularly how systems initially prepared in far-from-equilibrium states can evolve in time to a state which appears to be in thermal equilibrium.(no content)A variety of experiments in cold atomic gases have indeed observed thermal relaxation in systems which are, to a very good approximation, completely isolated from their environment.

## Non-Thermalizing Systems

Not all systems thermalize. Many-body localization (MBL) is a phenomenon where quantum many-body systems retain memory of their initial condition in local observables for arbitrary amounts of time.(no content)The process of thermalization erases local memory of the initial conditions.

## Key Thermalization Properties

In thermalizing systems compared to non-thermalizing ones, in thermalizing systems, a memory of initial conditions is not accessible in local observables at long times, while in MBL systems, memory of initial conditions remains accessible.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Autocorrelation function physics"

Links: [{"title":"Autocorrelation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autocorrelation"},{"title":"Correlation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation_function"},{"title":"Correlation function (statistical mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Correlation_function_(statistical_mechanics)"},{"title":"Optical autocorrelation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optical_autocorrelation"},{"title":"Partial autocorrelation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_autocorrelation_function"},{"title":"Spectral density - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_density"},{"title":"Dynamic light scattering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_light_scattering"},{"title":"Autocorrelation technique - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autocorrelation_technique"},{"title":"Wiener–Khinchin theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org//wiki/Wiener–Khinchin_theorem"},{"title":"Autoregressive model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autoregressive_model"}]

I found comprehensive information about autocorrelation functions and their applications in physics. Here are the key findings:

## Definition

In statistics, the autocorrelation of a real or complex random process is the Pearson correlation between values of the process at different times, as a function of the two times or of the time lag.

## Physics Applications

The autocorrelation function has several important applications in physics:

**Optics and Spectroscopy:**
- Autocorrelation analysis is used heavily in fluorescence correlation spectroscopy to provide quantitative insight into molecular-level diffusion and chemical reactions.
- Another application of autocorrelation is the measurement of optical spectra and the measurement of very-short-duration light pulses produced by lasers, both using optical autocorrelators.
- In optics, normalized autocorrelations and cross-correlations give the degree of coherence of an electromagnetic field.

**Particle Analysis:**
- Autocorrelation is used to analyze dynamic light scattering data, which notably enables determination of the particle size distributions of nanometer-sized particles or micelles suspended in a fluid.

**Astronomy and Materials Science:**
- In astronomy, autocorrelation can determine the frequency of pulsars.
- In surface science and scanning probe microscopy, autocorrelation is used to establish a link between surface morphology and functional characteristics.

## Mathematical Relationship

The Wiener–Khinchin theorem states that the autocorrelation function of a wide-sense-stationary random process has a spectral decomposition given by the power spectral density of that process.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Spin models statistical mechanics"

Links: [{"title":"Ising model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ising_model"},{"title":"Spin model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_model"},{"title":"Spin–statistics theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin–statistics_theorem"},{"title":"Spin chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_chain"},{"title":"Spin (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_(physics)"},{"title":"Spin glass - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_glass"},{"title":"Quantum Heisenberg model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_Heisenberg_model"},{"title":"Classical XY model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_XY_model"},{"title":"Potts model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potts_model"},{"title":"Heisenberg model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heisenberg_model"}]

Here's what I found about spin models in statistical mechanics:

## Overview

The study of the behavior of such "spin models" is a thriving area of research in condensed matter physics. Spin models are mathematical frameworks used to understand how magnetic systems behave at a statistical level.

## Common Types of Spin Models

The Ising model describes spins (dipoles) that have only two possible states, up and down, whereas in the Heisenberg model the spin vector is allowed to point in any direction.(no content)In certain magnets, the magnetic dipoles are only free to rotate in a 2D plane, a system which can be adequately described by the so-called xy-model.

## The Ising Model

The Ising model is a mathematical model of ferromagnetism in statistical mechanics. The model consists of discrete variables that represent magnetic dipole moments of atomic "spins" that can be in one of two states (+1 or −1).(no content)Neighboring spins that agree have a lower energy than those that disagree; the system tends to the lowest energy but heat disturbs this tendency, thus creating the possibility of different structural phases.

## Spin Chains

A spin chain is a type of model in statistical physics. Spin chains were originally formulated to model magnetic systems, which typically consist of particles with magnetic spin located at fixed sites on a lattice.

## Applications

The lack of a unified theory of magnetism forces scientist to model magnetic systems theoretically with one, or a combination of these spin models in order to understand the intricate behavior of atomic magnetic interactions. Numerical implementation of these models has led to several interesting results, such as quantitative research in the theory of phase transitions.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Ergodicity Breaking Arising from Hilbert Space Fragmentation in Dipole-Conserving Hamiltonians" and populated the `triples_output.json` file with 9 key triples.

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution** - The paper proposes novel findings about Hilbert space fragmentation and ergodicity breaking in dipole-conserving systems.

**Triples Identified**:
1. **Hilbert space** (concept, uses) - Mathematical framework for quantum systems
2. **Ergodicity** (concept, proposes) - Main finding: ergodicity breaking mechanism
3. **Charge conservation** (concept, uses) - Key conservation law studied
4. **Fracton** (concept, uses) - System type with dipole conservation
5. **Spin model** (concept, uses) - Physical model investigated (spin-1 models)
6. **Thermalisation** (concept, uses) - Phenomenon studied (breakdown of)
7. **Autocorrelation** (method, uses) - Measurement technique employed
8. **Quantum random circuits** (concept, uses) - Comparison framework
9. **Eigenstate** (concept, uses) - Non-thermal eigenstates examined

All validation checks passed successfully, confirming that:
- Paper type is properly set as "contribution"
- At least 1 "proposes" relation exists (ergodicity breaking)
- All papers have at least 1 "uses" relation
- All Wikipedia URLs are valid and properly formatted

Sources:
- [Hilbert space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_space)
- [Ergodicity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity)
- [Charge conservation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge_conservation)
- [Fracton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fracton_(subdimensional_particle))
- [Spin model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spin_model)
- [Thermalisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermalisation)
- [Autocorrelation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autocorrelation)
- [Quantum random circuits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_random_circuits)
- [Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis)
